metadata.title: Recent advances of porous transition metal-based nanomaterials for electrochemical energy conversion and storage applications

Recent advances of porous transition metal-based nanomaterials for electrochemical energy conversion and storage applications
Wei Jin a, b, *, Govindhan Maduraiveeran c, **
a Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Biological Colloids, Ministry of Education, School of Chemical and Material Engineering, Jiangnan University, Wuxi 214122, China b Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 1th Ber-er-tiao Zhongguancun, Beijing 100190, China c Materials Electrochemistry Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Chennai, Tamil Nadu 603 203, India
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 27 December 2018 Received in revised form 2 April 2019 Accepted 30 April 2019
Keywords: Porous transition metal Functional nanomaterials Electrochemical method Energy conversion Energy storage
* Corresponding author. Key Laboratory of Synth Ministry of Education, School of Chemical and Ma University, Wuxi 214122, China. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: wjin@ipe.ac.cn (W. Jin), madu (G. Maduraiveeran).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mtener.2019.04.016 2468-6069/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Rational design of earth-abundant porous transition metal-based nanomaterials (PTMNs) is of great importance for developing next-generation electrocatalysts of electrochemical energy devices. The development of inexpensive catalysts would meet the demand in the energy sector. Due to the perfect match between the porous features (large surface areas, high pore volumes, modulated pore structures) and transition metal advantages (unique d electron configurations, low cost nature, synergistic effect of multi-metal atoms, excellent stability), there is significant advance for the energy systems of electrochemical supercapacitors (ECs), batteries, water splitting and fuel cells (FCs). In this review, we systematically discuss the recent achievements in the typical oxides, sulfide, phosphide and carbrides of PTMNs for electrochemical energy storage and conversion. The novel design, fabrication, and applications performance of these nanomaterials are illustrated and compared. The current challenges and future prospects of PTMNs in EESC applications are also provided. We believe that this timely and critical review will stimulate increasing extensive studies and attract more attentions, further improving the development of promising PTMNs.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Recently, over 80% of the global energy consumption stems from non-renewable fossil fuels including coal, oil and natural gas [1,2]. The rapid combustion of these traditional fuels significantly leads to the CO2 emission, climate change and environmental pollution. To obtain a sustainable economic growth and environmental balance, it is crucial to pursue clean and renewable energy systems [3]. As a result, there is a growing demand for electrochemical energy storage and conversion (EESC) devices owing to their superiorities of ultrahigh energy and power densities, long-term durability, low cost and large-scale portable feasibility. In order to achieve these requirements, high performance nanostructured electrode materials are highly needed. Three key properties offered by
etic and Biological Colloids, terial Engineering, Jiangnan
raiveeran.g@ktr.srmuniv.ac.in
nanomaterials are the corresponding small size, high surface area and facile stress relaxation [4]. It should be noted that porous nanomaterials can provide additional combinations of large internal reactive surface areas, straightforward mass and electron transport through broad “highways”. Porous nanomaterials can be classified into three main categories with respect to their pore size: microporous (pore size below 2 nm), mesoporous (2 nm < pore size < 50 nm), and macroporous (pore size above 50 nm) systems [5,6]. Indeed, abundant morphologies are also generated with hierarchical porous structures, in which micro- and mesopore offer high surface areas while macrospore facilitate accessibility to the surface [7]. To date, considerable efforts have been devoted to design novel porous nanostructures for EESC, such ordered porous silica, carbon, and even polymer [8] (as shown in Fig. 1). And it can be seen that both the citation and publications of this field increases nearly >35% every year due to the significantly increasing attentions.
A variety of earth-abundant porous transition metal-based nanomaterials (PTMNs), such as oxides, sulfide, phosphide and carbrides, have recently emerged as promising alternatives for next-generation electrocatalysts [9]. There is a perfect match
between the porous features (large surface areas, high pore volumes, modulated pore structures) and transition metal advantages (unique d electron configurations, low cost nature, synergistic effect of multi-metal atoms, excellent stability), which is particularly beneficial for the EESC systems of electrochemical supercapacitors (ECs), batteries, water splitting, fuel cells (FCs) devices [10]. Besides, engineering porous channels configurations with transition metal-based nanomaterials is one of the most effective strategies to eliminate the severe aggregation of other one-dimensional (1D) and two-dimensional (2D) electrode materials. It should be stressed that ECs and batteries are electrochemical energy storage devices, whereas water splitting and FCs are typical electrochemical energy conversion systems. Unfortunately, the widespread commercialization of these innovative EESC technologies is still greatly limited by their high cost, poor durability and operability issue [11]. Therefore, rational exploration and design of new PTMNs can boost the ongoing electrochemical energy technologies, to satisfy the increasing urgent clean and renewable energy demand [12].
As shown in Table 1, preparation strategies of porous transition metal family nanomaterials generally group into five categories: template methods (soft- and hard-template), hydrothermal/solvothermal methods, electrochemical methods, deposition methods (chemical vapor and atomic layer depositions), etching methods. Considerable efforts have been devoted to investigate PTMNs growth in terms of dimensions, composition, pore structures, surface-interface chemistry. And it can be seen that different
fabrication techniques possess varied products [13,14]. As a result, ordered, non-ordered and hierarchical transition metal-based nanomaterials can be readily designed and fabricated. Herein, we systematically summarize the recent trends in the typical oxides, sulfide, phosphide and carbride of PTMNs for EESC [15]. The novel design, fabrication, and applications performance of these nanomaterials are illustrated and compared. The current challenges and future prospects of PTMNs electrode materials in EESC applications are also provided. We believe that this timely and critical review will stimulate increasing extensive studies and attract more attentions, further improving the development of promising PTMNs.

sections.heading: 2. Porous transition metal oxides
sections.text:
Many transition metal oxides (TMOs) have been successfully fabricated in the forms of porous structures with different morphologies, structures, crystal phases and pore size distributions, including TiO2, Co3O4, NiO, CeO2, WO3, Fe2O3, MnO2 and also mixed oxides in the spinel or perovskites forms [16,17]. In this section, we discuss the synthesis and electrochemical energy applications of typical porous transition metal oxides, due to their attractive features of great mechanical strength, high thermal and chemical stability, bio- and environmental compatibility, flexible surface chemistry and architecture, abundant oxygen vacancies/defects. A proper design of micropores, mesopores and macropores, which
omaterials (PTMNs).
can act as reaction sites, distribution/evacuation channels is also illustrated.

sections.heading: 2.1. Titanium dioxide
sections.text:
TiO2 is a naturally existing oxide of titanium, and usually it stems from anatase, rutile and brookite. TiO2 nanomaterials with porous nanostructures have beenwidely used in the dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs), supercapacitor, water splitting and lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) [18]. It has been identified that self-organized porous TiO2 structures can be achieved with optimized electrochemical treatments. For more than 60 years, compact TiO2 oxide layers can be formed by anodization in aqueous electrolytes, while their crystal structure are strongly dependent on the operated electrochemical parameters. When fluoride ions are introduced into the electrolyte with suitable anodization, a completely different growth morphology to ordered nanotubular/nanoporous TiO2 as schematically shown in Fig. 2. Schmuki et al. [19] well summarized this electrochemical method of the TiO2 nanotubes fabrication, which may be simplest, cheapest and most straightforward technique for PTMNs. Normally, the light-harvesting efficiency of the DSSCs is determined by a monolayer of adsorbed dye on the porous nanocrystalline TiO2, which is made by sintering a colloidal oxide particles paste with 10e30 nm sizes [20,21]. Jennings et al. [22] reported oriented TiO2 nanotube arrays (tube lengths 5, 10 and 20 mm) prepared by anodization of titaniummetal can offer an attractive alternative to solegel TiO2 films due to the combination of large surface area and tunable pore geometry. And nearly 100% collection efficiency for photoinjected electrons is achieved in the nanotubes-based cells.
Besides, the mesoporous TiO2 has also been widely explored [23]. Brezesinski et al. [24] developed the template nanocrystalbased mesoporous TiO2 film for the efficient electrochemical capacitors, exhibiting ~1.7 times higher than the highly ordered films made from a solegel precursor. Recently, it has been reported that there are additional fascinating nanoconfinement effects in mesoporous TiO2 [25] (as shown in Fig. 3). The 3D nanoscale frameworks can generate surface and quantum effects, which is beneficial for
Fig. 2. Schematic set-up for anodization experime
solar cells, water splitting and batteries. In the perovskite solar cells [26,27], the organic halide perovskites act as both solid state light absorbing and hole transporting agents, while themesoporous TiO2 is employed as a channel to confine the perovskite pigments growth. As a result, a power conversion efficiency of 20.1% under 100 mW m 2 AM1.5G illumination can be reached, as compared to the conventional ones of 12.1% or even much lower.

sections.heading: 2.2. Nickel oxides
sections.text:
Electrochemical capacitors (ECs), also known as supercapacitors, have been demonstrated as one of the most promising energy storage devices due to their many superiorities of higher power density than batteries, rapid charge-discharge and long life time [28]. Thus, ECs have the potential to bridge the recent gap between conventional capacitors and batteries/fuel cells. The porous NiO and their composites possess multiple oxidation states, high reversible capacity, large surface area, hierarchical porous structure, good structural durability, and have been widely used as emerging electrode materials for ECs [29]. It should be noted that the rich porosity can provide considerable channels for the fast electron transport and decrease the volume distortion in the longterm cycling, significantly enhancing the cycle performance and life. The theoretical largest capacitance of NiO materials is nearly 2584 F g 1, however, this theoretical capacitance has not been achieved experimentally owing to its limited electrical conductivity (0.01e0.32 S m 1 ) [30].
Besides, when the NiO loading increases, the NiO is densely packed and then reduce the accessible surface area for charge storage. Notably, Liang et al. [31] developed a 3D nanoporous NiO film (264 m2 g 1 surface area) via a two-step electrochemical process, exhibiting a large specific capacitance (1776 F g 1), power density (89 Wh kg 1) and energy density (16.5 kW kg 1). In Fig. 4, Wu et al. [32] reported two-dimensional (2D) ultrathin porous NiO nanoflake arrays, which are vertically deposited on the surface of 3D nickel foam through a solvothermal process followed by air sintering. Remarkably specific capacitance (2013.7 F g 1 at 1 A g 1) and cycling durability (100% capacitance retention over 5000
nts. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [19].
cycles) is achieved. Furthermore, it is found that the mesoporous NiO crystals can provide dominantly exposed ｛110｝reactive facets for the ultrafast electrochemical energy storage, in which the charge transfer can be significantly improved [33].

sections.heading: 2.3. Manganese oxides (MnOx)
sections.text:
Mn-based oxides present wide applications in supercapacitors, primary and secondary batteries due to their excellent activity, earth abundance and environmental friendliness. For example, primary ZneMnO2 batteries accounted for nearly 90% of the total sales, themixedMnO2 and carbon nanomaterials have been usually
employed as the cathodes of ZneMnO2 batteries from the year of 1860 [34] (as shown in Fig. 5). However, primary batteries cannot be recycled and have serious environmental concern. The rechargeable batteries can obtain the stable conversion between electrical and stored chemical energy, particularly lithium ions batteries (LIBs), in which MnxOy cathode can be reversibly cycled through the conversion between oxides and metallic phases. It has been reported that the ordered mesoporous structure can accommodate the volume changes and provide the diffusion channels of Liþ ions, leading to the improvement of cycling and rate performance [35]. Chen et al. [36] synthesized nanoporous g-MnO2 hollow nanocubes and microspheres by a hydrothermal route
combined with thermal treatment. The as-prepared nanomaterials presented the first discharge capacities of 1289.0 and 1992.6 mA h g 1, respectively. And it has been identified that the performance of MnO2 is usually in the order of g > a > b.
Besides, controlling the morphology of manganese oxides nanomaterials is also a general pathway to improve the EESC performance. Hussain and Lu [37] presented (Fig. 6) that the porous cobalt-doped zinc manganese oxides has a specific capacitance of 1196 F g 1, which can be well-organized into the hybrid supercapacitor device. And Li et al. [38] reported that high specific capacitances of 937 F g 1 can be achieved in the MnO2eMneMoO2 sandwich-like nanotube architectures, to overcome the bottleneck of low electrical conductivity of MnO2 (10 5～10 6 S/m). Clearly, the porous architecture provides new opportunity for the application of these earth abundant transition metal oxides in the next generation high performance ECs.

sections.heading: 2.4. Mixed transition metal oxides (MTMOs)
sections.text:
The mixed transition metal oxides (MTMOs) of single-phase ternary transition metal oxides with two different cations, are emerging as alternative electrode nanomaterials for both LIBs, ECs, oxygen evolution reaction (OER), oxygen reduction reaction (e.g. the rate determining step of metal-air batteries and fuel cells) [39].
Their exceptionally high electrochemical activities are resulting from complex chemical compositions/valences, rich donoreacceptor chemisorption sites, higher conductivity and potential synergetic effects. Spinels are a class of MTMOs with AB2O4 formula, in which the crystal is a cubic system, has been recently used as the anode materials for lithium-ion batteries and cathode materials for fuel cells [40]. Mondal et al. [41] (as shown in Fig. 7) developed the mesoporous NiCo2O4 nanoflakes and nanobelts as the anode materials for LIBs, and their large specific capacities of 1033 and 1056 mAh g 1 are much larger than the 372 mAh g 1 of commercial graphite anode. It should be noted that these values also exceed the theoretical capacity (890 mAh g 1) of NiCo2O4 due to the 3D porous structure. Besides, Wang et al. [42] developed the hollow porous spinel ZnMnxCo2 xO4 microspheres for the oxygen reduction reaction of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), exhibiting excellent activity and durability of 1.00 V onset potential and 6.2 mA cm 2 limiting current at 1600 rpm.
Another important MTMOs of perovskite oxide has a general formula of ABO3 or A1 xA01 yB1 yB0yO3, in which A is rare earth metals or alkaline earth and B is transitionmetals, respectively [43]. Suntivich et al. [44] (as shown in Fig. 8) summarized the ORR catalytic activity of the LaMO3 and LaNi0.5M0.5O3 (M¼Ni, Co, Fe, Mn or Cr) perovskite oxides, and identified that the ORR activity was largely determined by the B-site cation. Pham et al. [45] developed
the carbon- and binder-free 3D porous perovskite oxide LaNi0.9M0.1O3 (M¼ Cu, Co) nanosheets for lithium-O2 batteries. The as-prepared porous structure can significantly facilitate the gas and electrolyte diffusions, generate a well-organized electronic conductive network for efficient energy conversion. As a result, excellent ORR and OER performance are obtained in both aqueous and non-aqueous systems. As shown in Table 2, Zhao et al. [46] reported the high oxygen electrocatalysis performance can be achieved at the hierarchical mesoporous perovskite La0.5Sr0.5CoO2.91 (LSCO) nanowires, leading to the remarkable capacity of ca. over 11,000 mAh g 1 of lithium-air batteries (one order of magnitude larger than the corresponding LSCO nanoparticle). Besides, it has been demonstrated that further electrocatalysis improvement
can be obtained by incorporate the perovskite with carbon nanomaterials or other transition metal oxides.
3. Porous transition metal sulfides
For the past few decades, transition metal sulfides (TMSs) have emerged as one of the most prominent candidates for LIBs, ECs and water splitting [47]. They exhibit larger electrical conductivity, mechanical and thermal durability than those of the corresponding metal oxides, as well as richer redox chemistry than those of carbon-based nanomaterials [48,49]. The “inherent electrochemistry” mainly stems from the redox reactions at the TMSs surface under electrical field, which can partly eliminating the influence of
various conditions such as pH, applied potentials and the nature of electrolyte. However, the sluggish ion diffusivity and the low surface area significantly limit their EESC applications, addressing the necessarity to combine the porous features. In this regards, the recent advances of porous transition metal sulfides in EESC are presented, particularly the typical sulfides such as molybdenum
sulfides, cobalt sulfides, copper sulfides and important ternary sulfides systems [50].
3.1. Cobalt sulfides
The cobalt sulfides (CoSx) with various stoichiometric compositions of CoS2, Co3S4, CoS, and Co9S8 have attracted increasing interest due to their high electrocatalytic activity and electrical conductivity (6.7 103 S cm 1 at room temperature) [51]. Zhao et al. [52] (as shown in Fig. 9) reported a facile anion exchange of Co(OH)2 with sulfide ions to fabricate nanoporous hollow Co3S4 nanosheets, which can be also employed as a general preparation method to other metal chalcogenides. The as-obtained nanoporous hollow Co3S4 nanosheets are demonstrated to be highly active and durable for OER, exhibiting larger current density and lower onset potential than the corresponding solid Co3S4 nanosheets and commercial Pt/C. It should be noted that their small overpotential of 0.363 V vs. RHE at 10 mA cm 2 is even close to 0.266 V of most efficient OER catalysts RuO2. Furthermore, Cai et al. [53] developed the oxygen containing amorphous cobalt sulfide porous nanocubes through ionic exchange reaction on Prussian Blue Analogue (PBA) with S2 replacing Fe(CN)63 . The anionic exchange reaction generates porous structure consisting of a large amount of defect sites, while the introduction of oxygen into host can form more active CoeS bonds to facilitate O* adsorption for efficient water oxidation reaction.
Furthermore, it has been demonstrated that Co3S4 phase exhibits excellent catalytic activity for both ORR and OER. Sennu et al. [54] (as shown in Fig. 10) reported the fabrication of 2D mesoporous Co3S4 via simple hydrothermal process. The presence of unique mesopores with the synergistic effect of core/shell nanoparticles in the nanosheets presented superior energy performances as a negative electrode for a LIBs and LieO2 systems. An ultrahigh discharge capacity of 968 mAh g 1 after 60 cycles is obtained during the LIBs test, while the initial discharge capacity of 5917 mAh g 1 is achieved with an excellent reversibility of 96% for the LieO2 battery. Gu et al. [48] developed a high-efficiency noblemetal-free hybrid ORR electrocatalyst consisting of Co3S4 nanoparticles encapsulated in porous sulfur doped graphene, exhibiting identical performance with commercial Pt/C in both alkaline and acidic solutions.
3.2. Molybdenum sulfides
Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is a layered metal sulfide, where the MoeS atoms are covalently bonded and the adjacent layers are linked by van der Waals interactions. Yang et al. [55] (as shown in Fig. 11) constructed self-assembled porous metal oxides (general pore size ca. 5e10 nm) by facile and cost-effective anodization on metal substrates, then treated with sulfur vapor at 300 C to obtain porous edge-oriented MoS2. These films possess high surface area and 3D open architecture, leading to excellent hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electro-activity with improved kinetics and longterm cycling durability. Besides, Lu et al. [56] developed amorphous MoS2 porous thin film by simple hydrothermal reaction, in which the thiourea was employed as sulfur precursor at the Mo substrate. As a result, a small overpotential of 120 mV and a low Tafel slope of 41 mV dec 1 are obtained. Lee et al. [57] designed the 3D porous network weaving 1D carbon nanotubes and 2D MoS2 nanosheets, leading to excellent ORR electrocatalytic activity with better methanol immunity and higher durability than Pt/C.
It has been demonstrated that MoS2 is a promising anode nanomaterial for lithium-ion batteries since it possess three times the theoretical capacity of graphite However, the main challenges of MoS2 anodes are the structural degradation, low intrinsic electric
conductivity and large resistance upon cycling. In this regards, Chen et al. [58] (as shown in Fig. 12) designed hierarchical MoS2 tubular structures internally wired with carbon nanotubes (CNTs), leading to very high specific capacity of ~1320 mAh g 1, excellent rate capability, and long-term durability up to 1000 cycles. Liu et al. [59] developed a vacuum enhanced impregnation route to fabricate uniformmesoporous MoS2 with high surface area (130 m2 g 1) and narrow pore size distribution (4.3 nM peak). The obtained mesoporous MoS2 achieves a good discharge capacity of 876 mAh g 1 after 100 cycles. Ge et al. reported a facile and straightforward
electrochemical pathway for the fabrication of MoSx/graphene composite with great 3D porous structure, resulting a high specific capacity over 1200 mA h g 1 and superior cycling stability of LIBs.
3.3. Ternary transition metal sulfides
It has been demonstrated that ternary transition metal sulfides such as MCo2S4 (M ¼ Ni, Cu or Zn) exhibit much higher electrocatalytic activity and capacity than single-component sulfides owing richer redox states. It has been identified that MCo2S4
presents higher electrical conductivity than its corresponding oxide counterparts, while NiCo2S4 even has 2e4 orders of magnitude conductivity than NiCo2O4, nickel and cobalt oxides. Recently, Yu and Lou [60] systematically summarized the mixed metal sulfides (MMMs) for the electrochemical energy storage and conversion, revealing that the improved performance of MMMs is attributed to their high electronic conductivity and richer redox reactions. Besides, Mohammadi et al. [61] (as shown in Fig. 13) reported a facile self-template method to fabricate nanoporous CuCo2S4 microspheres, which can significantly improve the active surface area and conductivity. The as-obtained microspheres are demonstrated to be highly active and durable for supercapacitor, exhibiting 1566 F g 1 and superb cycling durability of 95.7% after 5000 test.
Based upon reversible Li2S conversion and/or Li-metal alloying scheme, considerable metals chalcogenide present about 2e3 times higher capacities than the commercial electrode materials. Nevertheless, the cycle service life and rate performance are still limited by the unstable materials structure, relatively low electrical and ion conductivity. Li et al. [62] reported amesoporous CoeZneS/ C-CNT derived from bimetalliceorganic-frameworks (BMOF),
which was employed as the anode material for LIBs with a large reversible capacity of 941 mAh g 1 after 250 cycles test. Besides, Zhou et al. [63] (as shown in Fig. 14) developed active and durable ternary molybdenum sulfo-selenide nanoparticles on selfsupporting porous nickel diselenide foam, which exhibits comparable hydrogen evolution activity with Pt catalysts and better than those of most binary transition metal dichalcogenides. This advance is due to the strategy by integrating metal dichalcogenides and pyrites inside 3D hybrid structure that have large surface area, porous architecture, favorable electrical conductivity and rich active edge sites. Therefore, the electrochemical energy performance of different TMSs is presented in Table 3.

sections.heading: 4. Porous transition metal carbides
sections.text:
The development of transition metal carbides (TMCs) can expressively alter the physico-chemical characteristics of the parent metals [64e69] (see Table 4). The TMCs are fundamentally developed through incorporation of carbon (C) atoms into the interstitial places of transition metals, such as all 3d-, 4d- and 5d-
ructures constructed from ultrathin nanosheets (CNT/MoS2 nanohybrid). (A) Illustration atic of the fabrication process for the CNT-in-tube structure. Reprinted with permission
elements of group 4e6 early transition metals. The TMCs often exhibit unique catalytic, electric conductivity, etc. [70e72]. For instance, the TMCs sometimes demonstrate exceptional catalytic properties which are distinctive of the high-cost Pt-group metals (Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir and Pt). Consequently, TMCs may possibly be employed as less-cost and high poison-tolerant materials to substitute Pt-group metals in heterogeneous catalysis and electrocatalysis. It is highly understood that the high concert of electrochemical energy conversion and storage devices are exceedingly reliant on the reaction of catalysts, electrode substrates and structure of double layer. Excessive advancement for the construction of nanostructured TMCs, in particular with hierarchical porous structures, with improved electrochemical performance has been achieved in recent years [73e75]. Engineering of porous structured TMCs based electrode materials are exhibited with improved increased electrochemical active surface area (EASA), higher active sites and adequate get in touch with area connecting analyte species and electrodes. These advantageous properties award porous-structured TMCs with enriched electrochemical properties for energy conversion and energy storage research [76e78]. The advances in the development of methods and electrochemical energy applications of porous TMCs (molybdenum carbides (MoC), tungsten carbides (WC), titanium carbides (TiC), etc.) and their nanocomposite materials will be discussed in the following section.

sections.heading: 4.1. Molybdenum carbides
sections.text:
Transition metal carbides (TMCs)-based nanomaterials, in particular, molybdenum carbides (Mo2C) have appeared as the cost-effective, great abundance, and good electrical-conductivity
electrocatalysts for various electrochemical energy areas [73,79]. It is well recognized that molybdenum carbides possess four different crystal structures, including a-MoC1 x, b-Mo2C, g-MoC, hMoC. These carbides based on molybdenum may potentially affect the electrochemical performance with variable compositions [68,80]. Recently, the ordered porous-structured TMCs nanomaterials have prompted growing interest in the field of as energy storage, separation, catalysis, etc. owing to their high dispersion of porosity, high active surface areas, large pore volumes, and inert surfaces [81e83]. Molybdenum carbide based nanomaterials have fascinated wide-ranging research devotion, especially as an effective hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalyst because of its dband electronic structure is analogous to that of Pt-group metals [65,68,82,84]. A variety of synthetic strategies have been established to fabricate MoxC-based nanomaterials with high porosity for various electrochemical applications. For instance, Huang et al. have recently prepared porous hybrid consisting of nitrogen-doped molybdenum carbide and phosphide, N@MoPCx-800 using pyrolysis method [74].
As shown in Fig. 15, the Mo4eCNPs are characteristic hexagons with about 60 nm in size. After processing with ultra-sonication, thinner Mo4eCNP nanosheets were simply attained. The TEM and SEM images exposed that the porous nanosheet was well-retained. The edge of the N@MoPCx-800 displayed that many N@MoPCx clusters had dispersed in the carbon network. The phase with a hexagonal nature Mo2C and MoP was obtained through X-ray diffraction of N@MoPCx-800. The as-developed N@MoPCx-800 nanosheets showed the homogeneous allocation of Mo, C, N, and P using the energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental maps. The N@MoPCx-800 showed the interplanar distances of 0.211 and 0.236 nm, ascribing to the (101) plane for MoP and (002) plane for
Mo2C, respectively. It is suggested that the presence of amorphous natured carbon, which could show significant activity in segregation the expansion of N@MoPCx and stabilize the structure of nanosheet. The Mo4eCNP precursor crystals controlled a molecular structure and a layer-by-layer packing crystal structure. The asdeveloped porous N@MoPCx-800 presented significant improvement of the electrocatalytic activity towards electrochemical hydrogen evolution. The porous N@MoPCx-800 demonstrated the onset potential of ~32mVwith a Tafel slope of 69.4 mV dec 1 under acid electrolyte. Wu et al. have also developed the structured mesoporous Mo2C core- and graphitic carbon-shell (Mo2C@GC) for the enhanced HER under acidic solution [73]. The Mo2C@GC showed improved electrochemical HER performance with a low overpotential (~125 mV), a small Tafel slope (66 mV dec 1) and an remarkable stability in acidic electrolyte due to its meso-structure offered escalating the active sites density, decrease the path for
electron transfer and facilitating mass transfer process. Wang et al. have developed Ni-decorated molybdenum carbide (Ni/Mo2C) hollow structure through dissolution-regrowth process for HER under alkaline solution [77]. Fig. 16(aee) presents the typical preparation scheme for Ni/Mo2C and its SEM, TEM and EDX elemental mapping analysis. The Ni/Mo2C(H800) electrode exhibited better HER activity than that of other electrodes investigated in the study, attained the current density of 10 mA cm 2 which required overpotential of 203 mV (Fig. 16). Cao et al. have fabricated hierarchically macro-meso-microporous Mo2C with 3D construction (3D-HP-Mo2C) [79]. The 3D-HP-Mo2C electrode materials demonstrated outstanding electrocatalytic performance towards HER in acid as well as in basic solution. The 3DHP-Mo2C as an anode also exhibited high specific capacity, good cycling stability and good rate capability towards LIBs due to its distinct 3D open structure with hierarchical macro-meso-micropores. The
PC: carbide and phosphide hybrid; GC: Graphitic carbon; HP: hierarchically porous; Rs: Nanorods; NPS: Nanoplates; HMG: hollow hemisphere-morphological structured macroporous graphene; NWs: nanowires.
OER h ¼ 320 mV PH: Polyhedron; NC: nanocapsules; Nanocapsules; NS: Nanosheet; HM: Hierarchical mesoporous; CC: Carbon cloth.
developed hierarchically porous-structured electrode offers abundant channels for faster and efficient transport of electrons and ions via the overall electrode. Very recently, Sun et al. have developed the porous-structured nanorod molybdenum carbide (Mo2C NRs) with enhanced electrochemical performance for Li2S and solid adsorption for polysulfides [85]. The as-developed Mo2C NRs was successfully employed as the bi-functional host material and immobilized into sulfur cathodes. The Mo2C NRs based electrode possessed the merit of embedding polysulfides on the host, which showed the adsorption energy in the range of 4.89 eV to 8.20 eV for Li2Sx (x ¼ 1, 2, 4, 6 and 8) as shown in Fig. 17. It is understood from the electrochemical results that Mo2C NRs primarily anchor and activate the Li2S with reduced the charging overpotential. Thus, the irreversible deposition of polysulfides is successfully controlled and possible exploitation of Li2S was improved. The developed electrode offered a capacity of 1298 mAh g 1 for LieS batteries at 0.1 C (see Table 5).

sections.heading: 4.2. Tungsten carbides
sections.text:
Over the past decades, tungsten carbides (WC) are comparatively less-expensive which have fascinated much attentiveness for electrochemical energy field because they can demonstrate Pt-like performance in catalysis and electrocatalysis [81,86,87]. The sequential advancement in materials fabrication over very recent years, the porous-structured WC nanomaterials have been creating
new opportunities in numerous electrochemical energy technologies, in particular, effective electrocatalytic hydrogen production from water [88,89]. Numerous synthetic strategies have been developed in recent years. For instance, tungsten carbide can be produced via the carburization of tungsten or tungsten precursor (usually WCl6, WF6 and W(CO)6) under high temperature or through ball milling processes. Park et al. have fabricated a series of well-defined mesoporous WC catalysts for ORR under alkaline electrolyte [90]. The pore structures of WC (WC-700-m, WC-800-m and WC-900-m) was studied by varying the reaction temperature, starting from 700 to 900 C in CH4 (25%)/H2 (75%) for 9 h. All the prepared WC nanoplates showed isothermal sorption distinctiveness of mesoporous nature and equally monomodal pore size circulation (6.6e7.2 nm). As shown in Fig. 18, the as-developed W2N for mesoporous WC disclosed regular porous-structure. Among the prepared WC catalysts, the WC-900-m showed an enhanced electrochemical ORR performance owing to the catalytic characteristics of WC phase, central carbide surface, and porous structured electrode. The Pd/WC-900-m also possessed a large electrochemical active surface area (ECASA) because of the huge distribution of Pd (4 wt%) nanoparticles over WC-900-m.
Li et al. fabricated hollow hemisphere-morphological structured macroporous graphene/tungsten carbide/platinum (HMG/WC/Pt) nanocomposite through synchronous high-temperature approach [92]. The polystyrene (PS) spheres are employed as key template for the establishment of three-dimensional hollow hemisphere structured graphene architecture which provide high electronic conductivity and structural stability for both WC and Pt. The asdeveloped HMG/WC/Pt nanocomposite electrode showed exceptional electrocatalytic performances towards ORR in 0.1 mol L 1 HClO4 solution. The high mass activity of 206 mA mg 1 Pt measured at 0.9 V which is ~85% higher than that of Pt/C (112 mA mg 1 Pt). In addition, the HMG/WC/Pt nanocomposite electrode exhibited high activity maintenance of 84.5% even after 2000 CV cycles as shown in Fig. 19. The attained the improved ORR performance of HMG/WC/Pt nanocomposite may be accredited to the following reasons: (i) the sp2 hybrid and pep conjugate of graphene offers HMG with a much more tremendous electron transport competency than that of Vulcan XC-72 carbon; (ii) the promising macroporous structures of HMGmay efficiently improve the mass transport process during electrocatalytic process; (iii) the smallWC nanoparticlesmay offer effective synergistic consequence on the Pt metal, led to significantly boosted ORR activity of the electrode. Recently, Wang et al. have synthesized porousstructured tungsten carbides (p-WCx NWs) on carbon cloth using of a plasma-assisted carburization approach [76]. The fabricated electrodes based on p-WCx NWs acted as superior hydrogen-
evolving cathode by performing HER activity with honset, h10 and Tafel slope of ~39 mV, ~118 mV and ~55 mV dec 1 in acid electrolyte, ~56 mV, ~122 mV and ~56 mV dec 1 in alkaline electrolyte, respectively. The p-WCx NWs/CC electrode was also sustain over 40 h of hydrogen production by applying the current density of 20 mA cm 2 without apparent worsening the electrocatalytic performance.

sections.heading: 4.3. Titanium carbides
sections.text:
Owing to high electrical conductivity, and excellent chemical and thermal stability, titanium carbides (TiCs), typical envoy of transitionmetal carbides (TMCs) basedmaterials with nanoporousstructures are of meticulous interest [92e94]. The durability of cubic system of the TiCs does not affected by the fluctuations of C:Ti stoichiometry ratios. The solid-state reaction or solid-state carbothermal method is considered to be a traditional synthetic strategy for the preparation of TiCs [95e97]. The metal or metal oxides with elemental carbon will react at high temperature in the range of 1500 and 2300 K. The high temperature is necessary in order to attain the TMCs due to the attribution of needful activation energy for the formation of TiCs. However, Flaherty et al. have synthesized porous TiCs films at room temperature through PVD method [98]. Fig. 20 shows the SEM images demonstrating the profile and top
views of the TiCs films which was developed by depositing 500 monolayers of Ti at a high pressure of 2.5*10 7 mbar. Reactive ballistic deposition (RBD) of TiCs offers immense controllment over central characteristics, including active area, refractive index, porous dimension, and pore size circulation. These results may be effected the properties of materials in numerous applications such as catalysts, optical coatings, etc. Foratirad et al. have recently fabricated TiCs ceramics with using gelcasting process with methacrylamide as a chain forming monomer, methylene bisacrylamide as a cross-linker monomer and tetramethylammonium hydroxide as a dispersant [99]. The average pore size of TiCs ceramics was calculated between 1 and 10 mm.
For instance, Gao et al. have developed two-dimensional (2D) porous titanium carbide (Ti3C2) using the exfoliation of Ti3AlC2 in HF solution for electrochemical supercapacitor applications under 3.0 M KOH [100]. The as-produced 2D-Ti3C2 showed the specific surface area (SSA) of 22.35m2/g with enhanced the electrochemical energy storage ability with a volumetric capacitance of 119.8 F cm 3 at 2.5 A g 1. The enhanced electrochemical performance of the 2DTi3C2 based electrode was due to the attribution of available rapid ion-transport channels. Recent reports also suggested that Ti-based electrode materials have been considered as the efficient lithium polysulfides, which can be applied for the LieS battery applications. Among other oxide based electrode materials offered large band
gaps, which may impede the electron transport, led to the low use efficiency of sulfur. The TiCs based porous structured electrode materials may adopt suitability by offering the both good electrical conductivity and strong adsorption ability to LiPSs [78].

sections.heading: 5. Porous transition metal phosphides
sections.text: Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) have expected growing devotion due to their exceptional physicochemical possessions and extensive electrochemical applications, including electrocatalysts, supercapacitors, and lithium-ion batteries [101e103]. Numerous phosphide systems such as Ni2P, CoP, Ni5P4,FeP, etc. were effectively explored towards various electrochemical energy applications [86]. The development of porous-structured TMPs nanostructures is another methodology that can be employed to progress the electrocatalytic activities. The production of homogeneous porosity of TMPs can be achieved via controlling experimental parameters of template agent, precursor concentration, reaction temperature, etc. It is established that the introduction of homogeneous porosity may prime to the acquaintance of added active catalytic centers, thus, expressively enlightening the catalytic performance of TMPs.

sections.heading: 5.1. Nickel phosphides
sections.text:
Owing to the unique physicochemical properties, nickel phosphides (NPs) have obtained much attention in recent years in the ground of electrochemical energy conversion and storage, catalysis, adsorption and separation, gas sensing, and biomedicine [104,105]. A huge amount of reports on the synthesis of nickel phosphides motivated on the fabrication of multipart and high energy expenditure, and gasesolid reaction under inert conditions over 300 C. Till now, the synthesis method for nickel phosphides and formation
mechanism with special microstructures or hollow structures may not been driven out well. Nickel phosphides with nickel-metal phases, including Ni2P are effective electrocatalysts for HER and OER because of their species diversity, competent and lowoverpotential. Recently, Wang et al. have prepared Ni12P5 hollow nanocapsule structured nanomaterials using hydrothermal method for OER under alkaline solution [75]. The average size of Ni12P5 nanocapsules was found to be ~20 nm, and the thickness of wall was ~3 nm. Fig. 21a shows the schematic representation of formation mechanism diagram of the Ni12P5 hollow nanocapsule. As
shown in Fig. 21b, the surface of red phosphorus was flat, no signs of rough prior to-reaction, revealing that red phosphorus is tricky to liquefy in pure water and an aqueous ethanol. The red phosphorus was progressively decomposed into phosphorus ions with increasing reaction time (Fig. 21c). Nickel phosphides shaped through the reaction of phosphorus ion and nickel ion had collected into a hollow nanostructure with the diameter of ~20e50 nm (Fig. 21d). The Ni12P5 nanocapsules exhibited the onset overpotential of 290 mV and the Tafel slope of 49.8 mV dec 1. Besides the OER activity, Ni12P5 nanocapsules showed improved specific
capacitance of 949 F g 1 at 1 A g 1. Yan et al. developed Ni2P polyhedron with a porous nature using in situ synthesis method [106]. The as-developed Ni2P polyhedron employed as the potential electrocatalyst displayed improved electrocatalytic performance toward the HER under acidic solution, with a low overpotential (158 mV) and a small Tafel slope (73 mV per decade). The porous Ni2P polyhedron also showed the structural stability with acceptable stability for the hydrogen evolution due to the metal sites with hydrogenpowerfully sufficient to avert the eliminate of H2, while Psites may temperately bond to intermediates, make a surface of proton and hydride acceptor sites. Jun et al. demonstrated honeycomb-like matrix of nickel phosphide nanomaterials with enhanced electrochemical performance for supercapacitors [107]. Fig. 21a shows the scheme for the reaction mechanism of phosphorization treatment and accompanied structural evolution process. In general, NaH2PO2$H2O employing as a precursor can easily produce PH3 reactant by a solid thermal decomposition reaction. The strong absorption of PH3 reactant at the surface of Ni(OH)2 nanosheets, the ion exchange reaction between diffused PH3 and internal OH occurred on the surface. The SEM images (Fig. 21(bed)) depicted that as the phosphorization process proceeded, the NixPy 2 nanosheets were also assembled by the interconnected hetero-NixPy nanoparticles. The fabricated ASC device delivered the specific capacitance of 187 F g 1 at a current density of 1 A g 1.

sections.heading: 5.2. Cobalt phosphides
sections.text:
Cobalt phosphide materials such as CoP, Co2P have expanded concentration in the pasture of electrochemical technology due to their extensive stoichiometric composition, worthy stability, low overpotential, high specific capacitance [101,108,109]. Numerous electrode materials based on cobalt phosphides were developed by mixing of catalyst powders with a solvent and appropriate polymer binder, and then modified on the surface of the substrate
[98,110e112]. The usage of polymer binder on the surface of electrode may slab the catalyst, decreasing the catalytic activity. It is very challenging task to organize size and dimension of pore of the electrode, led to loss in active surface area. The electrochemical deposition is a powerful another strategy to fabricate the electrode. The electrodeposited electrode substrate may be employed as an electrode, whose pore size and dimension, and composition can easily be controlled by scheming the conditions. In addition, the fabricated electrode is binder-free, supporting to improvement of active surface area. For instance, Kim et al. have fabricated the 3D porous CoeFeeP foam electrode through electrochemical deposition as a high act and sturdy catalyst for both OER andHER activities [113]. In order to optimize the ratio of Fe/Co of the catalyst, CoeFeeP films were prepared with Fe/Co ratio of 0.2, 0.4, 1.1 and 3.3. As shown in Fig. 22, the CoeFeeP filmwith the Fe/Co ratio of 1.1 (CoeFeeP-1.1) demonstrated the highest catalytic commotion for OER due to the attribution of valence electron transfer to Fe and P from Co. And the optimized electrode exhibited the OER (294mV at 10 mA cm 2) and HER (73 mV at 10 mA cm 2) in a basic solution. Chen et al. have demonstrated the electrochemical supercapacitance performance of the 3D porous nanosheets network of Co2P on a nickel foam (NF) electrode [114]. The developed CoP/NF electrode exhibited specific capacitance 2193 F g 1 at 5 mV s 1 which was calculated from CV studies. In the galvanostatic technique, the same electrode delivered a specific capacitance of 1189 F g 1 at 10 mA cm 2.

sections.heading: 5.3. Iron phosphides
sections.text:
Owing to the less-expensive, environment friendly, durable chemical stability and catalytic activity, iron phosphides (FeP) have received much interest. Numerous FeP materials, including FeP/ carbon cloth, FeP nanowires, FeP/CNT composites, porous FeP nanosheets, and FeP nanoparticles have been developed for various electrochemical applications [115e118]. In recent years, hollow
nanostructures as well as the highly porous structures of FeP materials were demonstrated because of their huge surface area and highly exposed active sites. For instance, Nie et al. have effectively produced the hollow mesoporous-structured FeP microcubes from Prussian blue (PB) for enhanced electrochemical hydrogen evolution reaction [119]. As shown in Fig. 23, the preparation method is an effective approach to produce carbon-coated hollow mesoporous FeP microcubes (HMFeP@C) with specific surface area (61.3 m2 g 1). This method depends on the in situ carbonization using organic ligands to achieve carbon-coated nanosized FeP microcubes, which will successfully avoids the agglomeration and coalescence of FeP nanocrystals. The prepared HM-FeP@C was greatly active for hydrogen production under acidic solution with less negative onset overpotential (25 mV), small Tafel slope (56 mV dec 1), and low overpotential (~115 mV) required to achieve current densities of 10 mA cm 2.
Recently, Ray et al. have fabricated porous-structured array of iron-doped nickel cobalt phosphide nanoplates over a carbon cloth (NiCoFexP/CC) [120]. The prepared NiCoFexP/CC electrode exhibited small overpotentials (39 at 10 mA cm 2; and 275 mV at 50 mA cm 2) towards the hydrogen evolution and oxygen evolution reactions (Fig. 24). Based on the developed NiCoFexP/CC catalyst the two-electrode cell (NiCoFexP/CCkNiCoFexP/CC) was made under alkaline medium, which can attain 10 mA cm 2 at 1.51 V. To understand the HER reaction mechanism on the developed catalysts, the electrochemical double layer is be formed with water molecules on the surface of NiCoFexP/CC electrode, which aids to weak the HeOH bond through electronic effects of synchronized metal center, the oxygen atom and the interface of the dangling P atom (Pd ) and H atom [120]. The nanoporous-structured heterogeneous catalysts continuation of numerous active sites on metals accesses the incidence of multiple valence cations with extra
complex electronic structures, and superior conductivity. Thus, the enhancement of catalytic activity is attained with a new-fangled range of ternary transition metal-based phosphides with porousstructures as high-performance catalysts for overall electrochemical water splitting.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions and outlook
sections.text:
The development of porous transition metal-based nanomaterials (PTMNs) with unique properties and architectures has led to great advances in electrochemical energy storage and
conversion. Here, we have reviewed the state-of-the-art of PTMNs (oxides, sulfides, carbides, phosphides) from methodologies for controllable design to the successful application in different energy devices. There is a perfect match between the porous features such as large surface area, high pore volumes, modulated pore structures; and transition metal advantages such as unique d electron configurations, low cost nature, synergistic effect of multi-metal atoms, excellent stability, which are particularly beneficial for the EESC systems of electrochemical supercapacitors (ECs), batteries, water splitting, fuel cells (FCs) devices. Over recent years, a lot of porous structured transition metal oxides/sulfides/carbides/phosphides have been synthesized and employed more in the field of electrochemical energy conversion and storage. Herein, some of major insights into their current challenges and future directions are highlighted to achieve high electrochemical performance of PTMNs.
(i) More systematic theoretical and experimental investigations are needed to optimize the design of these nanomaterials for each specific application. In particular, further development of the computationally-assisted design and fabrication of PTMNs is urgently needed for structureeactivity relationship prediction and reduction of the synthesis attempts. In addition, we may change a myriad of variables include reaction temperature, precursor concentration to the metal, reducing agent concentration, capping agents/stabilizers' concentration, and additives' concentrations.
(ii) The understanding of fundamental correlations between porous structure formation, dimension, composition and catalytic activity of PTMNs is required. It is highly understood that the researchers have demonstrated that many PTMNs have excellent catalytic properties through various test characterization methods. It is suggested to put more effort into the mechanism of action and simulation calculations in order to understand the integrated relationship of porous structure and electrochemical performance. It is a challenging task to develop definitive structureeproperty relationships. On this situation, the development of approaches for measuring the electrocatalytic/storage properties of individual, well characterized porous nanostructures may convey instantaneous advantages.
(iii) The choice of novel electrode materials like alloy, dopant, core-shell structure for furthering new functionality, high conductivity, chemical durability, and high surface area is a modern era. We may focus to employ numerous kinds of mono-, bi- and tri-metal oxides/sulfides/carbides/phosphides as nanocomposite in different electrochemical fields and investigate their performance in different directions, producing more active sites of the nanomaterials for target applications. (iv) Moreover, the preparation procedures are expected to be simplified and engineered for large scale and low cost production. The fabrication of PTMNs nanocomposites with less amounts of noble metal particles to achieve high catalytic activity. With the design and development of synthetic strategies and the in-depth understanding of the structural relation and catalytic reaction mechanism, the PTMNs would engage a key position in many practical electrochemical devices. Consequently, the remarkable evolution of porous transition metal-based nanomaterials enables a bright and exciting future for the emerging electrochemical energy applications.

metadata.abstractText: Rational design of earth-abundant porous transition metal-based nanomaterials (PTMNs) is of great importance for developing next-generation electrocatalysts of electrochemical energy devices. The development of inexpensive catalysts would meet the demand in the energy sector. Due to the perfect match between the porous features (large surface areas, high pore volumes, modulated pore structures) and transition metal advantages (unique d electron configurations, low cost nature, synergistic effect of multi-metal atoms, excellent stability), there is significant advance for the energy systems of electrochemical supercapacitors (ECs), batteries, water splitting and fuel cells (FCs). In this review, we systematically discuss the recent achievements in the typical oxides, sulfide, phosphide and carbrides of PTMNs for electrochemical energy storage and conversion. The novel design, fabrication, and applications performance of these nanomaterials are illustrated and compared. The current challenges and future prospects of PTMNs in EESC applications are also provided. We believe that this timely and critical review will stimulate increasing extensive studies and attract more attentions, further improving the development of promising PTMNs. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd.
